newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan seen shuffling cabinet on August 21.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan seen shuffling cabinet on August 21.

text.p: Taiwan was likely to bring forward a planned government reshuffle to August 21 with key figures in the new cabinet starting to unfold, a ruling Nationalist Party-owned newspaper reported on Thursday.

Premier Lien Chan told the Central Daily News that his cabinet would tender its resignation on August 21 -- a week earlier than a planned August 28 resignation -- to avoid possible schedule conflict with the ruling party's August 24-28 party congress.

"The party congress will have meetings until the afternoon on August 28, making it difficult to arrange a time for the cabinet to tender its resignation," Lien, who doubles as vice president and the Nationalists' vice chairman, said.
"The cabinet may resign a week earlier on August 21," Lien said in an interview with the daily on Wednesday.

As the premier, Lien has been under fire for the perceived deterioration of law and order after the kidnap and murder of a television celebrity's teen-age daughter, but analysts and local media have said Lien is giving up the post mainly to pursue his presidential ambitions.
The resignation is a formality and does not signal difficulty for the ruling party.

The newspaper, quoting high-level sources, said President Lee Teng-hui was expected to nominate lawmaker Vincent Siew as the new cabinet chief and foreign minister John Chang as vice premier next week.
The new cabinet will start operation on September 1.

Government sources have told Reuters that the ruling party has settled on Siew as its choice to lead a new cabinet once Lien, who was elected vice president in 1996, gives up the post to pursue his presidential ambitions.
Siew has repeatedly declined to comment on such an appointment.
Lien said he would have more time to help the president handle national affairs after stepping down as the cabinet chief, but declined to discuss his future career plan.

"The most important thing for me in the next two years is to do my best as the vice president. As for what I will do two years from now, to be honest, it's too early for any kind of planning at this stage," Lien said.
"Life is full of unpredictable factors," he said.

When asked about Taiwan's relations with arch-rival China, Lien told the newspaper Beijing should put aside sovereignty issues and resume negotiations -- suspended since mid-1995 after President Lee's U.S. visit -- with the island.
Beijing saw Lee's trip as an attempt to promote Taiwan independence.
Beijing has regarded Taipei as a rebel-held province, that one day should be reunified with the "motherland", since a civil war split them in 1949.

Taipei officially favours eventual reunification with the mainland, but maintains that reunification is impossible before the Communist Party drops its power monopoly and allows political liberalisation.
